It was only gradually during his convalescence hat Pierre lost the

A joyous feelng of freedom--that complete inalienable freedom natural
to man which e had first experienced at the first halt outside Moscow--
filled Piere's soul during his convalescence. He was surprised to find
that this nner freedom, which was independent of external conditions,

"Oh, how good! How splendid!" said he to himself when a cleany laid

the night on a soft clean bed, or when he remembered that the rench had
gone and that his wife was no more. "Oh, how good, how splenid!"

And by old habit he asked himself the question: "Well, and what hen?
What am I going to do?" And he immediately gave himself the answe:
"Well, I shall live. Ah, how splendid!"

The very question that had ormerly tormented him, the thing he had
continually sought to find--th aim of life--no longer existed for him
now. That search for the aim o life had not merely disappeared
temporarily--he felt that it no longe existed for him and could not
present itself again. And this very absnce of an aim gave him the
complete, joyous sense of freedom which contituted his happiness at

He could not see an aim, for he nw had faith--not faith in any kind of
rule, or words, or ideas, but fath in an ever-living, ever-manifest
God. Formerly he had sought Him inaims he set himself. That search for
an aim had been simply a search fr God, and suddenly in his captivity
he had learned not by words or resoning but by direct feeling what his
nurse had told him long ago: tha God is here and everywhere. In his
captivity he had learned that in Krataev God was greater, more infinite
and unfathomable than in the Arcitect of the Universe recognized by the

the far distance finds what h sought at his very feet. All his life he
had looked over the heads ofthe men around him, when he should have
merely looked in front of him ithout straining his eyes.

In the past he had never been able to findthat great inscrutable
infinite something. He had only felt that it mut exist somewhere and
had looked for it. In everything near and compreensible he had only
what was limited, petty, commonplace, and senseles. He had equipped

seemed to him. But even then, at moments of weakness as he ha accounted
them, his mind had penetrated to those distances and he hadthere seen

learned to see the great, eternal, and infinite in everyting, and

and infinite life around him. And the closer he looked the mor tranquil
and happy he became. That dreadful question, "What for?" whih had

To that question, "What for?" a simple answer was now always reay in
